title: Estrone glucuronide
text:
Estrone glucuronide, or estrone-3--glucuronide, is a <a href="conjugation%20%28biochemistry%29">conjugated</a> <a href="metabolite">metabolite</a> of <a href="estrone">estrone</a>. It is formed from estrone in the <a href="liver">liver</a> by <a href="UDP-glucuronyltransferase">UDP-glucuronyltransferase</a> via attachment of <a href="glucuronic%20acid">glucuronic acid</a> and is eventually <a href="excretion">excreted</a> in the <a href="urine">urine</a> by the <a href="kidney">kidney</a>s. It has much higher <a href="water%20solubility">water solubility</a> than does estrone. Glucuronides are the most abundant estrogen conjugates and estrone glucuronide is the dominant metabolite of estradiol.
When <a href="exogenous">exogenous</a> estradiol is administered <a href="oral%20administration">orally</a>, it is subject to extensive <a href="first-pass%20metabolism">first-pass metabolism</a> (95%) in the <a href="intestine">intestine</a>s and <a href="liver">liver</a>. A single administered dose of estradiol is <a href="absorption%20%28pharmacokinetics%29">absorbed</a> 15% as <a href="estrone">estrone</a>, 25% as <a href="estrone%20sulfate">estrone sulfate</a>, 25% as <a href="estradiol%20glucuronide">estradiol glucuronide</a>, and 25% as estrone glucuronide. Formation of <a href="estrogen">estrogen</a> glucuronide conjugates is particularly important with oral estradiol as the percentage of estrogen glucuronide conjugates in circulation is much higher with oral ingestion than with <a href="parenteral">parenteral</a> estradiol. Estrone glucuronide can be reconverted back into estradiol, and a large circulating pool of estrogen glucuronide and sulfate conjugates serves as a long-lasting reservoir of estradiol that effectively extends its <a href="terminal%20half-life">terminal half-life</a> of oral estradiol. In demonstration of the importance of first-pass metabolism and the estrogen conjugate reservoir in the <a href="pharmacokinetics">pharmacokinetics</a> of estradiol, the terminal half-life of oral estradiol is 13 to 20 hours whereas with <a href="intravenous%20injection">intravenous injection</a> its terminal half-life is only about 1 to 2 hours.
